course_title: Topics in Spanish Linguistics: The Inner Workings of Spanish

class_notes:
(Same as LING 410 1)


DESCRIPTION: This course seeks to develop the understanding of the inner workings of morphology and syntax in Spanish from a functional perspective with a focus on variation amongst geo-sociolinguistic dialects. In addition, students will explore the ways in which prescriptive norms affect and differ from the widespread dialectology of the Spanish language.
Some background in general linguistics, such as the one provided in Span/Ling 303, Span/Ling 304 or Ling 201, is recommended but not required. This course can be used as one of the required 400-level courses for the Joint Major in Spanish & Linguistics or for the Major/Minor in Spanish.
TEXTS: All readings provided by instructor and available in Canvas
EVALUATION: Evaluation will be based on class participation & attendance (10%), creative reflections, (40%), quizzes (30%), exploratory learning activities (10%), and a final research presentation (10%)
PREREQUISITES: One Foundational Course, preferably SPAN/LING 303 or SPAN/LING 304.
course_description: Upper-level research seminar on topics of Hispanic linguistics and communication, such as history of the language, bilingualism, or translation. Students may take multiple SPAN 410 courses provided that they focus on different topics.
